User.title: User
User.description: Represents a user of the Boss OS application.

subscriptionId.description: Reference to the user's current Subscription. (Relationship: User 1:1 Subscription)

Subscription.title: Subscription
Subscription.description: Represents a user's subscription plan in Boss OS.

planId.description: Identifier for the specific subscription plan (e.g., monthly, annual).

creditsRemaining.description: Number of credits the user has remaining for content generation.

coverRegenerationsRemaining.description: Number of cover regenerations the user has remaining.

Product.title: Product
Product.description: Represents a generated digital product in Boss OS, such as an E-book.

userId.description: Reference to the User that generated this product.

content.description: Structured content of the product, varies by productType.

coverImageUrl.description: URL of the generated cover image.

createdAt.description: Date and time when the product was generated.

Course.title: Course
Course.description: Represents a generated video course script in Boss OS.

userId.description: Reference to the User that generated this course.

tagline.description: A short, catchy tagline for the course.

description.description: A detailed description of the course content and objectives.

Trend.title: Trend
Trend.description: Represents a trending idea or topic in Boss OS.

rationale.description: Rationale behind why this topic is trending.

trendScore.description: Score indicating the popularity or potential of the trend.

source.description: Source of the trending information (e.g., Amazon PLR, Etsy Digital).

lastUpdated.description: Date and time when the trend information was last updated.

TrendingTopic.title: Trending Topic
TrendingTopic.description: Represents a topic and its usage count.

usage_count.description: How many times this topic has been used to generate a product this month.

last_month_usage_count.description: How many times this topic was used in the previous month, for trend comparison.

lastUpdated.description: When the count was last updated.

keywords.description: A list of lowercase keywords for searching.

firestore.reasoning:
The Firestore data structure is designed to ensure security, scalability, and ease of debugging, while adhering to the principles of Authorization Independence, Clarity of Intent, DBAC (Database-Based Access Control), and QAPs (Rules are not Filters). It leverages denormalization to avoid hierarchical authorization dependencies and simplifies security rules by structurally segregating data based on access requirements.

**Authorization Independence:**
Authorization Independence is achieved via denormalization of access control data. For example, the `products` subcollection under each `user` uses the `userId` field to determine ownership. This eliminates the need for security rules to perform `get()` operations on parent documents, which would violate atomic operations. The `Trend` collection is globally readable and writable only by admins (defined through the `/roles_admin/{uid}` collection), and the data integrity is upheld without relying on external data.

**Clarity of Intent:**
The structure explicitly defines ownership using path-based access control (e.g., `/users/{userId}/products/{productId}`). This approach makes it straightforward to implement security rules based on user ownership.

**DBAC (Database-Based Access Control):**
Global roles (e.g., admin) are managed through the `/roles_admin/{uid}` collection. The existence of a document for a user ID in this collection grants admin privileges.

**QAPs (Rules are not Filters):**
The structure supports secure `list` operations by ensuring that collections do not mix data with different access needs. For instance, user-generated products are stored under `/users/{userId}/products/{productId}`, ensuring that listing products under a user only returns the products owned by that user. Similarly, `/trends` can be read globally, as that entire collection has the same access requirements.

**Invariants:**
The structure ensures the integrity of ownership, timestamps, and denormalized data. Ownership is explicitly modeled using the `userId` field in the `products` collection, creating a strict link to the user who owns the record.
